text: ALICE DRISCOLL sits on the sofa of her psychotherapist's Westwood office. It is a hazy morning. Coastal fog obscur a view to the ocean. Alice looks away to keep from crying.
Brian left me. My wedding is off. Dr. Shemp SIGHS.
(continuing) What was that?
What?
You sighed.
Did I?
You did, clear as day.
I suppose I'm disappointed.
You're disappointed. For me or in me?
For you of course. Alice is silent.
(continuing) It's not unusual for a therapist to develop feelings about a patient especially after seeing them for a number of years, as I have you. Alice wipes her eyes.
Feelings.
Friendly feelings, fatherly feelings -- it's part of the process of transference and counter- transference. Would you like to tell me what happened?
I came home late from work --
Alice stares into the white vastness of a refrigerator em of everything save a few condiments.

I was hungry. As usual, there was nothing in my fridge. She closes the door and walks from her kitchen to her liv room. An easel stands by the window. Canvases, some finished, some not, clutter the room. Alice picks up a se keys from a table by the door.
Alice leaves her apartment and walks down the hallway.
I went to Brian's to see if he had anything. She stops just a few doors down and puts her key into the lock.
Alice enters an apartment different from her own only in decor. She heads straight for the kitchen. Hanging on the refrigerator is a picture of Alice anda handsome man, BRIAN, taken on a ski trip.

He left a letter. Right where he knew I'd find it. Alice opens the door and looks inside. Brian's fridge is barren as her own.  3. A letter hangs from the top shelf with Brian's name signe the bottom. She takes it down and begins to read.
Alice's session with Dr. Shemp continues.
It said he was going to Alaska. That it was something he'd always dreamed of doing and couldn't put it off any longer.
Had he told you about this? Alice shakes her head.
(continuing) So that's it? He's gone? Alice shakes her head.
Not quite.
Alice stops her brown Volvo in the loading zone. She gets out of the car and runs into the terminal.
Alice scans the "Departures" monitor looking for a flight Alaska. She locates one leaving for Anchorage through gat A26 at 8:30. She looks at the clock. It's 8:25.

Alice is at the security checkpoint leading to the gates. GUARD is checking her manually with his metal detector. S looks like she's about to burst The Guard finishes and waves her through. She snares her purse from the conveyor belt and runs towards Gate A26.

Alice arrives at the gate to find Brian's plane in the la stages of loading. She pushes through the crowd, searchin Parents are seeing off children, women give uniformed soldiers parting embraces. She spots a man in newly-purchased adventurewear bending to lift his backpack. BRIAN. He looks up and sees her. He doesn't appear completely surprised.
Did you get the letter?
Alaska? Have you lost your mind? We're getting married in four months. Brian withdraws, looks towards the gate.
(continuing) Aren't we?
I don't know. Maybe we should put that on hold.
On hold? Are we breaking up? What's going on? At the gate, a FLIGHT ATTENDANT picks up his microphone.
Last call for flight 018, service to Anchorage.
I'm sorry. This is something I need to do. I have to go. Alice and Brian lock eyes.
Alice's session continues.
So then he left -- Alice shakes her head slowly.
Brian turns to leave. Alice, without thinking, reaches ou and grabs hold of one of the straps on his backpack and p him towards her with surprising strength.
Then it got a little ugly.
Alice sits before Dr. Shemp, eyes cast down.
Ugly.
There was some yelling, I was crying and trying to stop him from leaving -- physically -- it's a little blurry, but I think a security guard was involved. But, yes. He did get on the plane.

Alice, her face streaked with tears, her hair and clothes mess, sits slumped in a chair watching as Brian's plane t away from the gate. A Security Guard observes from a safe distance. He looks sorry for her.
Had Brian ever exhibited impulsive behavior in the past?
No.
Any history of mental illness?  Alice shakes her head.
(continuing) What about his family?
Not that I'm aware of.
This isn't normal conduct. There must've been warning signs.

Brian was everything I ever told you he was -- patient, successful, kind, thoughtful, handsome -- are these the signs of latent psychosis? Silence. Dr. Shemp glances at a clock on the wall behind her.
I'm afraid our time is up. Alice takes her checkbook out of her purse and fills out check. Finished, she hands it to him.
(continuing) Perhaps over the coming week you should give some thought as to why you attract this kind of man.
Alice's car is parked beside a dumpster behind the museum She approaches the service entrance with a heavy bag slun over her shoulder.

The studio is chaotic, packed with little kids playing wi legos, finger paint, cutting shapes out of construction paper. They are loosely supervised by KATHIE and BRANDIE, two interns who are well-kept and ill-meaning.  Alice notices that a four-year-old BOY is systematically emptying cups of glue onto the table top. Kathie and Bran stand GOSSIPING, completely oblivious. Alice hurries up and takes a cup of glue from the kid's h
(to the interns) Didn't you notice what was happening here? Kathie and Brandie look at the mess on the table.
Oops. Guess not.
Clean this up, okay? Alice walks off. Kathie whispers to Brandie loud enough f Alice to hear.
I didn't realize there was a glue shortage. As Alice makes her way across the studio, she is intercep by JUDY, her paranoid middle-aged boss.
About your request for a door to your office. I'm afraid we're going to have to say no.
Did you look at it? The frame is already in place. All you need is the door.
We don't have any doors.
What if I paid for it myself? It's so noisy in here it's hard to get anything done.
I didn't want to get into this but we have codes.
Fire codes?
Among others, yes. Judy zips off. Alice sighs and heads for her office, a sm cubicle at the corner of the studio.
A WEALTHY WOMAN stands over Alice's desk changing her ove child, who, at the moment, is naked and wiggling.
What are you doing?
Hunter had an accident. The Wealthy Woman dumps a full and dirty diaper into Alic waste basket.
(continuing) You don't mind, do you?
Yes, I mind. This is my office.
How was I supposed to know?
(conducting a brief tour) Desk, file cabinet, telephone, office. The Rich Woman stuffs her child into a clean diaper.
There's no door.
What? The Woman picks up her child, preparing to leave.
Offices have doors.
Alice is eating ice cream in front of the television. She sets the bowl down on the coffee table.  9. Her cat jumps up and licks up the rest. She reaches out a scratches behind his ears.
Hello, Mr. Fabulous.
Alice wakes up, having fallen asleep with the television She shuts it off and sits up putting her head in her hand
Alice enters Brian's dark and empty apartment
Alice crawls into Brian's bed and buries her face in his pillow.
It's the end of the day. Alice ushers the last few stragglers out the door. She pulls down an aluminum gate locks it. Kathie and Brandie are chatting as they clean up.
-- there I was sitting on a throne on the banks of the Nile.
What were you wearing?
A long gold dress with slits up both sides.
Like the Donna Karan we saw at the Beverly Center?
Exactly. I had a killer retro tan and bracelets winding up both arms like snakes. Alice walks by.  10.
What is this?
Kathie saw a past-life medium. Alice pauses to listen.
Anyway, there are these soldiers they're wearing these little leather skirts -- Brandie makes a face.
(continuing) They made it work. So they drag up this slave or husband or something and without thinking I say, "Off with his head!"
I have got to try this. Alice moves towards her office, keeping one ear on Kathie
(continuing) What's the woman's name?
Varya.
Alice is in another session. Dr. Shemp observes. His expression is impenetrable.
It's not fair, I miss him, and I don't even get to be mad at him because he's not here.
Perhaps we should explore where this anger is coming from.
I think it's a natural reaction.  11.
We're not talking about what's natural, we're talking about you.
I thought I was getting married and now I'm not. This hurts me. Because I'm hurt I want to lash out.
Perhaps you're really angry with your father. Alice elects to ignore this interpretation.

I realized last night that the world is primarily unfair. I know it sounds obvious, look at the Holocaust for God's sake. It's not a logical thought, more the sudden realization that I've lived my life believing that things come around, that good things happen to good people, that life affords us compensation equal to our suffering. But it's all delusional bullshit, isn't it? Do you believe in past lives?
What do you mean? In the sense of a Jungian collective consciousness?
No, in the I was the third wife of Henry the Eighth sense.
I'm more from the object relations school -- Winnicott, Fairbairn, good breast, bad breast --
There's a good breast and a bad breast?
According to Melanie Klein, yes. Alice looks at her own breasts in turn.  12.
I had no idea.
Alice is watching television in sweats. Mr. Fabulous is o her chest, PURRING. A half-empty bowl of popcorn sits on coffee table next to a half-empty bottle of wine.
They're showing the "Wizard of Oz."
(to Toto) There's no place like home. Alice reaches for the remote and shuts off the set.

(to Dorothy) Speak for yourself. Alice carries the popcorn bowl to the kitchen. The place amess. She dumps the bowl in the sink. She spots the Yellow Pages, thinks, and pulls it from the shelf. She plops herself down at the table and looks up a listin She finds it under "V" in a very small box. The ad reads: Varya Past Life Medium "Escape to Yourself" Alice reads off the number and reaches for the phone. She stops herself just as she's about to dial.
(to herself) Come on, Alice, get a grip.

Alice lies in bed, tossing and turning, unable to sleep. Glancing at her alarm clock, she sees that it's two in th morning.  13. She rises from bed, taking her clock with her. She gather up Mr. Fabulous and leaves the room.
Alice lies sleeping in Brian's bed with Mr. Fabulous curl up on top of her. Hearing FOOTSTEPS approaching, Mr Fabulous wakes and looks around. A key SCRATCHES in the doorway. Alice half wakes.
Brian? Alice sits up, comes to her senses. It can't be Brian. Sh hears the sound of someone entering the apartment.
(continuing) Oh my God. Alice gets herself out of bed and to the door. She opens a tiny crack and looks through.

What appears to be an INTRUDER enters the apartment. He's wearing coveralls and is carrying a cardboard box. Someth in a soft case is hanging from his back. His hair is shag and unkempt but it's too dark to make out his face.

Alice backs away from the door, terrified. She picks up t phone beside the bed but there is no dial tone, it's been disconnected. There is a lot of THUMPING around outside. Alice is begin to panic. She hears FOOTSTEPS coming towards her. Alice slips into the closet and shuts the door.

Alice can hear that the intruder has entered the room. Sh gropes around for something to defend herself with and fi an old fraternity paddle. The intruder tries to pull open the closet door. Alice sl it shut from inside. There is a pause.  14.
Hello? Alice says nothing.
(continuing) Is this Brian Doon's apartment?
It's Doan. Brian Doan. who are you?
I'm Kevin.
Kevin who?
Just Kevin, I'm his sublet Alice peeks out the door. KEVIN stands before her, holdin Mr. Fabulous who seems quite comfortable.
(continuing) Do you live here?
No. I -- She puts down the paddle.
(continuing) I guess I don't need this.
Is this your cat? Alice nods.
(continuing) Nice cat. Are you a homeless person? I could come back.
No, I live here, in the building, I'm sorry -- She takes Mr. Fabulous from him.  15.

(continuing) I'll get out of your way. And she is gone. Kevin goes to his box and opens it. It is full of groceri He finds a banana, peels and eats it. He takes a carton o milk and carries it to the fridge. He looks at the pictur of Alice and Brian on the door.
Banana in hand, Kevin wanders into Brian's bedroom and fl on the light. The imprint of Alice's body is still clearly visible on t right side of the unmade bed.

Sunday morning. Alice stands before a blank canvas waitin for inspiration. She dips her brush into a blob of yellow ochre but is wra with indecision and cannot apply it. She puts down her brush and soaks a wad of newspaper with paint thinner. The solvent highlights a classified ad for Varya, the pas life medium. The ad is identical to the one she saw in th Yellow Pages.

Referring to an address written on a scrap of paper, Alic walks up to the door of a normal-looking house somewhere Los Feliz. She reaches out and knocks hesitantly. A VOICE (with a faint Eastern European accent), calls out from inside.
Yes? Who is it?  16.
It's Alice Driscoll, I had an appointment for noon. The door BUZZES. Alice pushes it open and walks inside.

Wind chimes move gently in the breeze from the skylight above. The walls are covered with abstract paintings. Ali pauses to look at one of them. VARYA enters from the living room, drying her hands on a dishcloth. She is a handsome woman in her early forties a is dressed casually.
Hello, I am Varya. They shake hands.
Nice to meet you. (of the painting) Did you do this?
(of the painting) It is my brother's. I am not an artist, I have little interest in suffering. But you, I see, area painter.
How did you know? Varya points to Alice's hands which are lightly stained w paint.
You're a little early, come -- Varya leads her down the hallway.
Varya and Alice are sitting at the kitchen table eating grilled cheese.  17.
It would be better if there were tomato soup.
This is great, I wasn't expecting lunch. Varya takes the last bite of her sandwich and wipes her h on a napkin.
So. Tell me why you are here.
Someone at work was talking about you. I saw your ad. I usually don't go for this sort of thing.
But you are in a time of stress.
Yes.
And you were curious.
I am curious.

Our eyes illuminate only a dim path before us and our memory distorts what we leave behind. A dark curtain obscures everything else. I imagine that there are people in the world who never wonder what is behind the curtain. I find this very strange. Varya takes their plates to the sink and rinses them unde the tap.
(continuing) Have you ever had the feeling you have lived other lives?
I've always hoped there was something more than this.  18. varya fills a silver bowl with about an inch of water.
You were raised a Christian?
Catholic, yes.
But you no longer practice. Varya returns to her seat and places the silver bowl betw them.
I haven't been in a church since I was ten. Alice watches as Varya wets her index finger in the bowl. holds it above the surface of the water.
Leaving an emptiness you try to fill with your art. Innocent blood, the beauty of martyrdom --
-- peace on earth and sexless unions. Alice watches a drop of water fall from Varya's finger in the bowl. The waves ripple and return in slow motion.
Do you feel comfortable leaving here now?
Yes.
Shall we go back? Alice is transfixed by the water.
We shall.

If you find yourself somewhere you don't like, simply say the word "help" and we will go to another place. Do you understand?  19. Alice nods. She watches as another drop falls from Varya' finger. Alice hears the sound of HOWLING WIND. The water in the b darkens, eddies, and closes in, filling her entire frame vision. Alice retreats into her trance.
(continuing) Tell me where we are.

The water runs between the banks of the river Neva in St. Petersburg. An ebony troika is pulled briskly along the riverbank by two spirited white stallions. Sitting in the troika is a BEAUTIFUL WOMAN, wrapped in gr sable, a member of the Russian aristocracy circa 1850.

I think it's Russia, yes, in the time of the Czars. The woman and her troika and her magnificent horses gallo past, revealing an awful sight. TWENTY PEASANTS are bound by long ropes to a barge of coa and are being used as human oxen to pull it up river. At the head of the line are two massive, toothless PEASAN WOMEN whose backs have nearly been broken by hard labor. The second one in line speaks to the first.
Pull harder, Alice, the day is short and our husbands are drunkards. The first peasant stops in her tracks.
Did you say my name was Alice?
Help.  20.
Dark, heavy clouds give way to a deep blue sky and rollin green hills.

Where are we now? A lovely white house is nestled in a wooded bower. A new model T Ford is parked in the garage. A very handsome MAN wearing work clothes circa 1920 searches the yard. He loo distressed.
Alice! Alice! Where did you go? (looks around) Alice!! The Handsome Man goes inside the barn for a look
The Handsome Man can be heard calling out from inside.
Alice! Chickens, geese, and ducks scatter at the sound of his vo The handsome Man comes out the rear door of the barn, see only from the waist down. He stops.
There you are. A large TURKEY stands frozen in fear, staring at the Hand Man, who is revealed to be holding a well-sharpened ax.
(continuing) Happy Thanksgiving, Alice.
Help.
Varya is at the stove pouring two cups of tea. She shakes her head.
This is very unusual.  21. Varya sets the tea down at the table and resumes her seat
I don't know why I thought my past lives would be any better than this one.
Could we try once more?

A 1960 Ford pickup ambles down a dusty road in the Deep South. It passes by a roadside diner called JUMBO'S and keeps going. A woman sits on the front step, smoking a cigarette. She wears checked pants, a cook's shirt, and has a short apro tied around her waist. Her hair is falling out of the bobby pins that have been haphazardly stabbed here and there. ANNE CARVER is the spitting image of the Alice of today.
It looks like I'm a cook ina diner. Somewhere in the Deep South.
Would you like to go somewhere else? She looks up. Three long black Cadillacs are coming towar her at a pretty good clip.
Wait. Approaching the diner, the Cadillacs slow and turn into t parking lot.
(continuing) Let's see what happens. Anne crushes her cigarette under her heel and heads back the diner.  22.

A small, clean place with six tables and six booths. It i mid-afternoon and completely empty. A waitress named DORI sits in the corner booth over a magazine and a cup of cof She hears the JINGLE of a bell over the door and looks towards it. Four men swagger in. Their hair is lifted and slicked bac they wear black jumpsuits with the collars turned up and their pant legs are tucked into their boots. Wrap-around sunglasses shield their eyes. They are known as the MEMPH MAFIA. Two more MEN follow closely behind. The first has a fat, jowly face and a cigar crammed into corner of his mouth. This is COLONEL TOM PARKER. He uses cane purely as affectation. The second is a modest Young Man in a tweed sport coat an black tie. Doris's jaw drops as she recognizes him.
Is it -- are you -- him?

Yes, ma'am, I'm Elvis Presley. Elvis sits with the others. Doris approaches and takes ou her pen and order pad but her hands are shaking and the p falls to the floor near Elvis's feet. Elvis picks it up and hands it to her.
(continuing) I think you'll be needing this.

Doris approaches the line, behind which Anne and Junior nervously await. She tears a chit from her order pad and puts it beneath t spring on the order wheel, then she does it a second time and a third, and a fourth, and to Anne's astonishment a f before spinning the wheel towards them.  23.
Order in.
Anne and Junior move through the kitchen preparing the Ki order. Doris sits off to the side on a milk crate.
Who'd have thought a man could be that pretty and still be such a man? She looks into a small pocket mirror and applies red lipstick.

(continuing) My heart skid to a stop when he smiled at me. Junior looks at the order. He reaches into a drawer, coun off three hamburger patties, and slaps them on the grill where bacon sizzles near a neatly cornered pile of hash browns. Anne slides open a refrigerated drawer beneath the cuttin board and removes a covered pan. Turning back to the stov she fires the burner under a second skillet and pours in oil.
Which order is his?

The five bacon and mustard sandwich. Junior flips four slices of white bread into a four slice toaster. Moving down the line, he stirs up a bowl of hush puppy batter and dollops silver dollar sized portions int the heated skillet.
(continuing) Do you think he'd take offense if I asked for his autograph?
Definitely not. Elvis isa generous man.  24. Anne shakes a layer of cornmeal directly onto the cutting board and smooths it evenly with the palm of her hand.

What do you know about Elvis? She reaches into the pan and fishes out two catfish fille which have been marinating in mustard, cream, and various spices. She holds the fillets above the pan, allowing the marinade to run off.
I pick up a newspaper now and again. (to Doris) Get one for me too, would ya?
He ain't gonna be in sucha generous mood if you burn those hush puppies. JUMBO shakes the pan and starts turning them with a fork.
(continuing) What are you going to have him sign? Anne rolls the catfish fillets in the cornmeal and lowers them carefully into the skillet
I don't know, I hadn't given it any thought.

The Memphis Mafia is horsing around; doing the spot trick balancing unscrewing the caps to the salt and pepper shak trying to keep Elvis entertained. Doris approaches, balancing all six of their plates. She sets down Elvis's first, then Colonel Parker's, then the others. JOE, the mafia's ring leader, takes Doris aside and whisp something naughty in her ear.  25.
Anne peeks out from behind the line. Elvis catches her looking at him. She quickly turns away, pretending to be busy.
Elvis looks over his sandwich. He removes the top slice o toasted bread and reaches for the salt shaker.
Anne is watching again. She cringes. Elvis is about to dump the salt when he changes his mind sets the shaker down.
(to herself) Good boy.
Elvis reassembles his sandwich. He raises it to his mouth and takes a bite. Chewing slowly, he finds himself transported into a state of complete bliss. The Colonel notices and looks at him funny.
What is it, boy? You all right?
This is the best damn sandwich I ever had.
The Memphis Mafia leaves the restaurant. Elvis is already gone. Colonel Parker waits behind in the booth, chomping his cigar. Anne approaches from the kitchen.
You asked to see me? Parker offers the seat across from him. Anne takes it.  26.
Elvis has been looking for someone who can come to Los Angeles and cook so as he doesn't get homesick while he's working there. Are you married?
No, sir.
Kids? Anne shakes her head.
(continuing) Bad habits?
I like to sleep in on Sundays.
Are you a fan?
I don't understand.
A fan, an Elvis Presley fan?
I've heard Mr. Presley on the radio, but I must confess, his music does not move me.
Junior is ringing out the register. Anne sits on a booth before it. Outside, one of the Cadillacs pulls away. The other one stays behind.
I'd be hard pressed to name one good reason for you to stay here.
There's you. Doris hops out of the back seat of the second limo and ru to the door as it pulls away.  27.
You think I'll starve to death? Go Doris bursts into the room.
Did he do it? Doris takes her underpants from her pocket and holds them out. "Elvis Presley" has been signed across the butt in b broad strokes.
He made you take them off?
That was my idea.
Alice has awoken from her trance in a big way. She sits across from Varya with her eyes open wide.
You have to send me back!
I'm afraid your time is up.
Alice is in her session. Dr. Shemp looks uncharacteristically nervous.
You don't really think you were a short order cook in a past life, do you?
It was fun, it seemed real enough at the time.
Freud said, "To live without a dream is impossible, but to live within a dream is insanity."
You think I should stop seeing her.  28.
I don't tell you what you can and cannot do, that would be directive.
(to herself) Why Elvis? I've never really been that much of a fan.
It's natural to go through a state of denial. You've lost your fiancee. On the list of major stressors, it ranks closely with the death of a loved one.
Which is sandwiched right between moving and losing your pet.
There are healthier ways to deal with stress. You could go for a walk, or try diaphragmatic breathing. Alice looks at him.
You're right, I'm acting like an insane person. I'll call and cancel as soon as I get home.

Kevin sits in the window box with his guitar on his lap a piece of peanut butter toast in his mouth. He strums a fe awkward chords and hums something before chewing his bite puts down the toast and looks out the window.
Alice leaves the building, holding a small paper sack. Ke watches her unchain her bike and pedal off.
Varya opens the door to find Alice standing there, holdin her paper sack.  29.
I brought this. She fishes out a can of Campbell's Tomato Soup.

Carrying her suitcase in her hand, Anne steps from the walkway into the main terminal of LAX, and into the large group of people she's ever seen gathered in one place. She sets down her suitcase and opens her purse. She searc anxiously until she finds a well-thumbed piece of paper w instructions written on it
Anne steps into a taxi cab and hands the piece of paper t the DRIVER. He glances at it briefly and pulls away from curb.

A throng of GROUPIES have gathered at the scrolled iron g outside Elvis's home away from home, hoping to catch a glimpse of the King. Anne's taxi pulls into the drive. A SECURITY GUARD takes a look at her identification, chec her name off a list, and shows her through. The Groupies look on enviously as she passes.

Anne rolls down her window as Elvis's mansion comes into view. The lawns are perfectly manicured, the bricks are washed white, a tacky fountain sprays water into the air. BEEP! BEEP! A souped-up golf cart driven by a Memphis Maf member shoots across the drive, forcing the CAB DRIVER to make an abrupt stop. Three other carts follow right behind, one of them is dri by Elvis, though they're moving so fast it's hard to tell
The taxi pulls away and Anne carries her small suitcase t the front door. She sets it down and rings the bell.  30. MAGGIE, a middle-aged housekeeper, answers.
Hello, my name's Anne. I'm the new cook.
Maggie. Thank God you're here. Maggie relieves Anne of her suitcase.
(continuing) Let me show you your room.
As Maggie leads the way up a curving staircase, Anne can' help but gape at the crystal chandelier, the opulent paintings and statuary, the marble floor, and the impossi high ceilings.
Anne is alone in a pretty little room which has a view on the drive. Her suitcase is open and she is unpacking. Hearing the ROAR of engines, she goes to the window and l out.
Elvis and the Mafia are firing up their motorcycles. Elvi has a Harley Davidson, the others ride Triumphs. Anne watches as they pull out in wing formation with Elvi leading the way.
Something startles Anne as she turns back to her suitcase Colonel Parker is standing in the doorway, watching her
I didn't mean to frighten you.
With all the noise, I didn't hear you coming, Colonel Parker.  31.
No need to be so formal. You can call me Colonel Tom. Do you have everything you need?
It's beautiful, thank you.

A few rules before you start. You're here to cook, that's all. Elvis is a busy man, he doesn't need any friends and he don't need any advice. Any private life happens outside those gates. You're here because Elvis wants you here, but you are employed by me. If there are any problems you come to me first and last, understood?
Yes, sir. Colonel Parker turns to leave and pauses at the door.
Supper's at six.

Anne is hard at work in Elvis's modern (c. 1965) kitchen. slips into hot pads, opens the oven door, and slides out perfect sweet potato pies. She sniffs them as she sets them out to cool. Removing her oven mitts, she reaches for a pastry brush a stainless steel bowl.
Racks and racks of ribs cook slowly over white hot coals. Anne gives them each a generous coat of BBQ sauce.

Anne takes a damp towel from four loaves of freshly-risen bread. She adjusts the oven temperature and slides them inside. She fills a glass of water at the tap and tosses it into bottom of the oven, filling it with steam to brown the cr  32. Moving to the fridge, she opens it and takes out four egg She cracks them into a copper bowl and whisks them until they're frothy. On a covered platter are sectioned pieces of frying chick She dips the chicken into the beaten egg and dredges them spiced flour. She does this with four other pieces and lays them into a shallow pan of hot oil.
Elvis, Col. Parker, and the Memphis Mafia are seated arou the table. what is left of Anne's magnificent meal is spr out before them.

So I find this one girl, she's willing, she's pretty, but she's too damn tall. So she introduces me to her friend, just as good- looking, maybe even better, but she couldn't have even made five feet I tell them this isn't going to work out, that Elvis likes a girl of average height. And the tall one says, how about we both go, it'll even out. LAUGHTER from the Mafia. Colonel Tom smirks and lights a cigar. Elvis doesn't even notice. He reaches for another piece o chicken and takes a bite. He shakes his head, unable to believe how good it is. Maggie enters to clear the table. She reaches for Elvis's plate and he stops her hand.
I'm just beginning to hit my stride.

Anne is putting whipped cream on the sweet potato pie. A tray of homemade peanut butter cookies is beside it, alon with an icebox cake.  33. Maggie enters carrying an armful of dirty plates. She unloads them at the sink.
I've always known those boys were pigs, but I've never seen them eat like this before. Anne is pleased.
(continuing) Elvis would like you to come out and say hello when you've got a minute. Anne freezes. She ditches her apron and starts working on her hair.
Everyone sits around the table, smoking, drinking, and yukking it up. Elvis is dipping cookies in milk. Anne enters through the swinging doors. Jimmy looks up.
How'd you get in here? Anne points to the door.
Through there, through the kitchen
Relax, boy, she's the new cook.
I thought you were a fan.
No, sir, I am a paid employee.
You don't look like no cook.
And what is that supposed to mean?

I just make the food, I don't put it in your mouth.
You don't have to make it so good.
I also accused him of running your life.
You did?
(continuing) You're not afraid of anyone, are you?
Not lately. Anne's left arm begins to quiver. She hides it behind her back.
If I talk to the Colonel, will you stay?  69.
Don't tell him I'm going to hold my tongue, because apparently I'm not capable.
Wouldn't dream of it. The quiver becomes a shake. Anne clamps onto her left han with her right, trying to still it.

Now leave me be, I have to unpack. Elvis smiles and leaves the room. Anne releases her arm. tremors spread from her arm to her shoulders. Then, her whole body begins to shake. Frightened, she slips into her bathroom and locks the doo

She sits down on the toilet, still shaking. She takes dee breaths trying to control herself, but her will does not her own. After a moment, the tremors pass. She goes to the sink an finds some aspirin. She looks at the mirror and meets eye with her reflection.
Anne sits on a bench in an examining room, looking fright and spent. DR. NORTHROP, early sixties, kind, enters with clipboard.
Hello, Anne, how are you feeling?
Better. Fine, actually.
(refers to chart) You say this is the first time you've had a seizure of any kind. There's no history of epilepsy in your family?
No, sir.  70.
Have you had any headaches, nausea?
Headaches.
Have you noticed or has anyone commented on sudden mood swings or changes in your personality?
Yes. Dr. Northrop thinks a moment. He hands his chart and a pe to Anne.
Would you sign your name here?
What am I signing?
Nothing, it's a test of your motor skills. Anne takes the pen and signs. She finds it surprisingly difficult. The resulting signature is an uncontrolled squiggly mess.
Red stands beside his car, holding the door for Anne. She slides inside and he closes it behind her.
Anne and Red ride down Wilshire Blvd. Red shakes two Tareytons out of their pack and hands one to Anne.
So what'd the doctor say?
Nothing really. He gave me some pills, wants me to come in for more tests. Red ignites his Zippo and passes it to Anne. She lights h cigarette and takes a deep drag.  71.
(continuing) Could you not tell Elvis I was here?

Anne is out on the patio in a sundress and hat. A book is open on her lap. Her eyes are closed and she has dozed of Elvis comes out of the house. He is about to say somethin when, noticing she's asleep, he pauses to look at her. He approaches cautiously, kneels down, and shakes her arm Anne opens her eyes.
What are you doing?
I was sleeping. It is my day off.
Feel like keeping the boss company?
Anne waits while Elvis kick starts his “57 Harley. The engine jumps to life on the second kick with a loping ras
(over the sound of the motor) Hop on! Anne bunches her dress up between her legs and climbs on behind him. Elvis dumps the bike into gear and they take off.

Elvis and Anne sweep down the curving, tree-lined street heading east through Beverly Hills. Anne has one arm arou Elvis's waist and is clutching her hat with the other to it from blowing away. Elvis cracks the throttle to make a pass. Anne shrieks happily.  72.

Anne is in the control booth of a Los Angeles recording studio. An ENGINEER sits at the control board. Colonel Parker is in attendance as is the Director of the film. The Colonel does not appear pleased to be sharing space w Anne.

head_text.subj: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE SOUNDPROOF GLASS

text: Are Elvis, four BACKUP SINGERS, and his BAND. The band is the final stages of setting up. The Sound Engineer speaks into his intercom.
(through speaker) Elvis? We're ready. Should we start with "Davey Jones' Locker"?
The Director turns to Anne.
(smiling proudly) I wrote that one myself.
Elvis looks over the music on his bandstand. He leans ove his microphone.
It's a little early in the morning to take on that masterpiece. I think I'd better warm up first. The Band Members and Backup Singers CHUCKLE.
(continuing) Any requests?
I've got one. The Sound Engineer directs her to the microphone.  73.
(into mic) Could you play "So Glad You're Mine"?
I thought you weren't a fan. Anne smiles and leans back to avoid the Colonel's glare.
Elvis turns to his Band.
(continuing) You boys remember that little blast from the past?
I think we can manage. Elvis nods to the drummer. He counts off a free bar and t begin to play.

(sings) My baby's long and tall, she's like a cannonball, said every time she loves me, lord you can hear me squall -- I cried, ooooowee, I believe I changed my mind. I said I'm so glad I'm livin', I cried I'm so glad you're mine.
Elvis pilots his bike into the parking lot of a Cadillac dealership on Wilshire Blvd. in Beverly Hills.
Elvis is inspecting a shiny new convertible. It is silver blue with a white interior and a white top. Anne stands b trying to get her hair back under control.
It's a pretty car. Are you going to buy it? A DEALER approaches.  74.
I already did. The Dealer hands Elvis the keys. He offers them to Anne.
(continuing) I bought it for you. It takes a moment to sink in.
It's a nice thought, but I won't accept.
I can't take it back.
Of course you can.
No, I can't, get in. Elvis opens the door for Anne. She gets in and slides ove to the passenger seat. Elvis sits down beside her
Elvis points to a custom gold plaque set in the dash. Ann looks. The plaque has been engraved: To Anne Carver. Love, Elvis For some reason this makes her sad.

(continuing) When I was a little boy, my daddy was sent to prison for writing a bad check. My momma worked her fingers to the bone for me. She used to pick cotton in the fields and drag me behind her on a burlap sack. When I started making money, I wanted to pay her back for all she'd gone through raising me. I bought her a nice new house in Memphis as soon as I could. The neighbors got upset with her “cuz she was keeping chickens in the yard and they didn't want no livestock in their neighborhood. (more)  75. ELVIS(continuing) I never knew that chickens were livestock, but what can you say? She just didn't fit in. Then I bought Graceland and moved her and my Daddy in with me. She could do whatever she wanted at Graceland and I think for a while she was happy.
Is Graceland as pretty as its name?
I think so.
I'd like very much to see it someday.
I'll make sure you do.
Promise?
Promise. So what about the car?
You can't buy people's love.
No, but you can buy them Cadillacs. Anne thinks about it.
I don't have a license.
Anne's new Cadillac is circling the drive. The car swerve wildly, its speed increasing with each loop.
Anne is driving, having the time of her life. Elvis sits beside her, genuinely frightened.
Brake, hit the brake.  76. Anne keeps accelerating. They veer off the driveway, head straight for the garage. Elvis reaches over with his foot and stomps on the brake.
The massive Cadillac skids to a stop just a few feet shy the garage door.
Elvis breathes a sigh of relief.
(continuing) Your stopping could use a little work. He looks to Anne. Her arm is across the steering wheel an her head is leaned up against it.
(continuing) What is it?
Headache. It came on so suddenly.
Elvis sits alone at the kitchen table over a plate of col fried chicken and cole slaw. He is drinking a Pepsi, look over the lit-up L.A. basin. Maggie approaches and reaches for his plate.
Finished? Elvis nods.
Elvis sits down at the piano. He lifts the cover and slow begins to play a spiritual.  77.
Anne's door is slightly ajar. Elvis knocks softly and enters. He goes to Anne's bed and sits down beside her.
Still hurt? Anne nods.
(continuing) Here. He gently props her head up on a pillow and massages her temples with his fingertips. Anne's face eases as some of the tension is released.
Elvis wakes in Anne's bed. The drapes are open, allowing harsh light into the room. Elvis is shirtless. He raises the covers and looks down.
Lord, what have I done --
Anne sits at the kitchen table in her robe. The newspaper and a cup of coffee are before her. Elvis enters the room jeans and a white t-shirt. Anne smiles at him and gets up from the table.
Good morning. Elvis sits down, searching for the will to speak Alice finds a cup in the cupboard and fills it full of co from a pot on the stove.
(continuing) Thank you for last night. Anne adds cream to the coffee and a lot of sugar. She set it down before Elvis and resumes her seat. Elvis takes a deep pull.  78.
(continuing) I do believe you have a healing touch.
What happened?
You don't remember?
Not past ten o'clock.
I was in a lot of pain. You laid beside me and helped me through it.
That's all?
(grinning) Pretty much.
Give it to me straight.
At some point in the night you must've stripped yourself out of your clothes, because when I woke up you were naked as a jaybird.
That wasn't you?
Please.
There are a lot of women who would pay good money to wake up and find me in such a state.
Even more who get to for free. Elvis thinks.
Did you look?  79.
I will not dignify that with a response.
I've got to keep myself pure, I've got a little girl waiting for me back in Memphis.
How old is she? Thirteen?
She's seventeen and I haven't laid a finger on her.
Do you love her?
Like she was my other half.
Are you going to do right by her?
I'm gonna give it everything I've got.
I have another question. She takes an instamatic camera from her pocket.
(continuing) Does Kodak develop X-rated photographs? Elvis snatches the camera from her hand.
Red waits behind the wheel of Anne's new Cadillac, readin the paper.
Anne sits on a lab table in a paper gown. Her head is clamped into a restraint that keeps it perfectly still. D Northrop prepares an injection. An X-ray TECHNICIAN atten  80.

This is an isotope which will allow us to observe circulation in the brain. It may hurt a bit. Dr. Northrop injects the solution directly into the carot artery in her neck. It hurts more than a "bit." The Technician positions an X-ray cassette changer behind head. He and the doctor retreat behind a protective scree A BUZZING sound is heard. The X-ray cassette rotates quickly, shooting off ten exposures in rapid succession.
Anne lies in bed. Red stands beside her.
Why are they keeping you overnight?
The tests they do on me make me sick.
Still no idea what's wrong? Anne shakes her head.
My doctor's meeting with a specialist tomorrow.
I'll tell E not to worry. Anne smiles thankfully and squeezes his hand.

Elvis, Red, some friends, and a small group of adoring YO WOMEN, have gathered in a paneled rec room. Elvis sits on the edge of the pool table, reading from the Bible. Gospe of St. Luke, Chapter 11; Verses 38 -- 41.

"Now it came to pass as they were on their journey, that he entered a certain village; and a woman named Martha welcomed him into her house. (more)  : : 81. ELVIS(continuing) And she had a sister called Mary who also seated herself at the Lord's feet, and listened to his word. But Martha was busy about much serving. And she came up and said, "Lord, is it no concern of thine that my sister has left me to serve alone? Tell her therefore to help me." But the Lord answered and said to her, "Martha, Martha, thou art anxious and troubled about many things; and yet only one thing is needful. Mary has chosen the best part, and it will not be taken away from her." Elvis closes the book and turns to his disciples.
(continuing) So what do you think?
I think Jesus is saying, "Don't let the daily grind drag you down focus on what's important."
That's good, baby. It ain't the work, it's the word. One of the Young Women is enraptured and is nearly fallin out of her dress.
Do you think Jesus was attracted to Mary?
It wouldn't surprise me. Don't forget, Jesus was half man.

Dr. Northrop and a SPECIALIST are looking at Anne's X-ray The circulation patterns in and around her brain are highlighted in bright relief. The Specialist points to an area in the lower middle part Anne's brain that appears as a blush. He circles the area with his pen. He moves on to another Ray which shows the area from a different angle.  82.
Anne is dressed and is sitting on a chair. Dr. Northrop enters, holding a chart. His face is the picture of conce
You have bad news, don't you?
Alice is at Varya's table.
Anne is dying.
Are you surprised?
Why wouldn't I be surprised?
When were you born?
(figuring it out) She has to die so I can be born?
Of course. It is a past life.
But Elvis loves her.
He told her that?
Not in so many words, but it's pretty clear. He bought her a car
What kind?
A Cadillac. Can't there be any overlap? Varya shakes her head.  83.
Convertible?
Yes. But her life is so much better than mine, it's not fair
That's a nice car.
Could I switch places? Cash in my life for hers?
Of course not.
I know this life, I've lived it for almost thirty years, I'm telling you, it's not so great.
Alice exits her office and walks up to Kathie who is help a little boy with his art project
Do you ever see Varya any more?
who?
Varya, the past-life medium. I heard you talking about her one day.
I'm over past lives.
You're over them.
I'm into colonics now.
(wishes she'd never asked) Really.  84.
They really teach you a lot about yourself.
A rare, clear spring day. Alice and Kevin sit on the oversized bench with their feet dangling. The view extend to the ocean. There are snacks and beers between them.
How'd you find this place?
I have a lot of important friends. (pause) What would happen if Brian came back today? She thinks about it. She nods.
I don't know. Why?
He sent me an address, a place to send my rent. Do you want it?
No, I don't think so.
You sure?
My shrink says that it takes half as long to get over a relationship as you were in it. I was with Brian for four years, so I guess I'll be over him in two.
What if you came across the right guy before that?
I'd probably walk right past him.  85.

I think the misery of sensitive people is caused by the fact that they are delivered into rigid environments formed by people of bad intent over which they have no control. Alice pretends to give this some thought
Sometimes I think I could get my nose pierced. She drinks from her beer.
(continuing) Were you really in a band?
Yes.
What happened?
Quit.
How come?
It became too much about the money. Alice laughs so hard she spits out her beer. Kevin hesita then smiles along with her.
Varya opens her front door and lets Alice inside.

Anne opens the oven and slides out a standing roast of pr rib. She and tests Convinced and shuts stabs a knife into the middle of it, pulls it out, the temperature with her tongue. it needs more time, she pushes the roast back in the door.  86. She disappears into the pantry and returns with a heavy canister of flour. It takes a lot of effort for her to ca it to the counter. Setting it down, she pauses to catch h breath and wipe the sweat from her brow. She goes to the fridge and takes out a glass bowl full of eggs. Returning, she begins to get woozy, her steps are unsteady. She closes her eyes and takes a deep breath, trying to regain her balance. An intense stab of pain hits her like a lightning bolt. T eggs fall from her hands. The glass bowl shatters. Her knees give way beneath her and she collapses on the floor
Elvis sits in the passenger seat wearing a U.S. Navy officer's dress uniform. Joe is at the wheel driving as f as he can. Red is in the back seat.
Did they say what kind?
It's in her brain, in a place they can't operate.
Anne is in a hospital bed, being fed through a tube up he nose. She opens her eyes to find Elvis sitting beside her bed, still in uniform.
You've been promoted.
I saved the crew from enemy capture. Made the world a safe place for democracy.
And the girl?
She waited for me.
Stupid girl.  87.
Why didn't you tell me?
I thought you'd go to pieces.
Do you want me to arrange for you to go home? Anne shakes her head.
(continuing) Aren't there people you should be with?
My Mother died a few years back. I wouldn't know my father if he was standing right in front of me.
No sisters or brothers? Anne shakes her head.
(continuing) Then we'll take care of you at the house.
I don't want to be a burden.
I've been honored by your company since the day we met. Elvis leans down and kisses her on the forehead.
You're taking this better than I thought you would.
I've always been a crying on the inside kind of clown. Anne closes her eyes.  88.
(continuing) Does it hurt much? Anne opens her eyes, nods slowly.
(continuing) Do they give you anything for the pain?
Morphine.
Should I call the nurse?
What time is it? Elvis looks at his watch.
Quarter past five.
It's okay, I get another shot soon. Could you wait until then?
Sure. Elvis takes her hand.

Elvis is in his room with Joe and Red and Jimmy and four PRETTY YOUNG girls. Half-full wine and whiskey bottles st about. Music plays on the radio. Elvis is all strung out, staring at the wall. Joe jokes w the girls, trying to keep things light. A Redhead sits beside Elvis. He turns and taps her on the shoulder
You think I could break that coffee table?
What do you mean?  89.
With my hand, like this. Smash right through the motherfucking table.
(laughs nervously) You're kidding, right? Elvis rises to his feet. He swipes the bottles, ash trays and other crap off the table with one sweep of his arm.
What the hell is going on?
I'm gonna break this table. Elvis stands over it. Gets in position, takes deep breath to psyche himself up.
That's pretty near four inches of mahogany.
I seen him break bigger boards --

It ain't gonna happen. (to Elvis) Break something else. Elvis holds up his hand, requesting silence. He squares himself, SHOUTS, and strikes the table with all his might If anything broke it was in his hand. The girls grimace. Elvis stands stock still. Red approaches.

(continuing) You all right? In a fit of temper, Elvis throws over the table and stomp it repeatedly with the heel of his motorcycle boot. No one knows what to do. Elvis keeps kicking the table ag and again. Realizing it's futile, he begins to calm down. He looks a the table. He looks at everyone in the room.  90.
That is one solid piece of furniture. Elvis smiles. The others breathe sighs of relief.

(continuing) I think I'm going to need another drink. Red turns up the radio. Joe picks up a bottle of wine and refills the girls' glasses. Elvis goes to the bar, which is set up on a piece of glas top of a dresser. His back is to the room. He slides open a drawer. Inside is a turquoise-handled Co .45 pistol. He drops the clip to check and see that it's loaded. It is. He takes the gun from the drawer and raises it up. One of the girls notices and SCREAMS. Elvis takes aim at the chandelier. BAM BAM BAM BAM BAM BA BAM BAM BAM! One by one he shoots out the glass shaded lamps. The marksmanship is not bad for someone who's probably had enough Demerol to stun an ox.
(continuing) I knew I could break something in this room. He sits down on the bed, still holding the gun. He is laughing, everyone else is quiet.

Elvis stands beside a slot-car race track, set up to mimi the Daytona Motor Speedway. He is wearing a karate gi wit large Yin and Yang symbol embossed on the chest. The track is realistic with grandstands filled with spectators, an astroturf infield with fake trees, and a p row with little plastic mechanics. He watches his car, a replica of a Plymouth Challenger circle the track. Anne enters dressed in a robe. She find a stool and sits down.  91.
I didn't know you were here.
They released me this morning. Don't you have to be at the set?
We finished on Friday.
What's next?
The Colonel's got something lined up.
You don't sound too excited.
Good money.
What do you want to do?
I don't know, play the piano. Did they tell you how long you have?
I've already lasted longer than they said I would. I appreciate that I can be honest with you.
Did you know I have a twin brother? Anne shakes her head.
(continuing) His name is Jesse. He died the day we were born. Elvis points to the Yin and Yang circle on his chest.

(continuing) As I go around this circle from good to bad, travelling through sin and temptation, Jesse is always with me. (more)  92. ELVIS(continuing) I know deep in my heart that I will see him again. That he and my mother and I will be together one day. As sure as I'm sure of that, I know that you and I will meet again, that we will be reunited at a different time and a better place. Elvis brings his car to a stop. He opens a drawer and tak out a red Mustang and a second control. He sets the Mustang in a slot beside the Challenger and h the control out to Anne.
(continuing) Wanna race? Anne takes the control. Elvis lines up the cars at the starting line.
Am I the Mustang?
Yeah.
I like Mustangs. Elvis picks up his control.
Ready?
Am I supposed to let you win?
Naw, cuz' if you do, I can just tell myself I was being a Gentleman.
So I can kick your country butt?
You can try.
And you won't pout?  93.
Pretty sure of yourself, aren't you?
Oh yes, very.
On three. One. Two -- Anne doesn't wait for three. She puts down her thumb and tiny car takes off.
(continuing) You little cheat!
Anne has dressed. She pulls some things out of the refrigerator, preparing to make lunch. Elvis enters in je and a t-shirt, his hair still wet from the shower.
What are you doing?
Making lunch.
You're white as a sheet. You should be resting.
Someone has to do it.

Anne is sitting at the counter. Elvis has taken her place behind it. He drops four slices of Wonder Bread into the toaster and pushes down the lever. Moving on to the stove he lights a burner and sets a skillet on top of it.

The most common mistake in the preparation of the fried peanut butter and banana sandwich is to not toast the bread. If you fall into this trap, you end up with a mushy sandwich that's cold in the middle.  94. He opens the fridge and finds a stick of butter. He lops an obscene amount of it and drops it in the pan. In the pantry, he searches and locates peanut butter and bananas Elvis picks up the frying pan and rolls it to spread the melted butter. The toast pops up. Elvis puts it on a pape plate and shows it to Anne. He opens the peanut butter and finds a knife. He scoops s out and slathers it on the bread.
(continuing) Don't skimp on the peanut butter either. A thick coat is applied to all four slices.

(continuing) You shouldn't be able to tell where the peanut butter ends and the bananas begin. Elvis puts two of the slices of bread into the frying pan The butter bubbles around them. He peels a banana and sli it onto the bread.
(continuing) You go lie down. I'll bring these to you when they're ready.

Anne sits on the sofa with a blanket wrapped around her l Elvis is beside her. A plate with the finished fried pean butter and banana sandwiches is on the coffee table besid two tall glasses of milk. Anne picks up a sandwich. She looks at Elvis's expectant face and takes a bite.
What do you think?
(swallowing hard) Good. Thank you. Elvis removes a heavy gold chain with a crucifix from his neck and places it on hers.  95.
Please, don't give me anything else.
I'm a performer. I don't give, I don't live.

Anne is in bed, the light is on low. She is taking deep breaths. Tears run down her cheeks. She is in great pain. Elvis enters the room. He moves quietly across the floor sits down on the edge of her bed. Anne grasps his hand and squeezes.

It's okay. Everything's going to be okay -- His presence has a calming effect on her. She lets his ha fall. He reaches up and applies pressure to her temples. Her breathing gradually deepens and evens.
(continuing) There's nothing to be afraid of -- Anne drifts off to sleep.
Alice. Alice. Alice!
Varya is on her feet, shaking Alice with all her might. S won't wake up. Giving up, Varya goes to the phone and punches a number.
I knew this one was crazy.
Varya's brother RALPH, a stout man in paint-splattered coveralls, stands on her doorstep. Varya opens the door.  96.
Ralph, good. Come in, come in -- Varya hustles him inside.
Alice sits at Varya's table. She is in a deep trance. The is the trace of a smile on her lips. Ralph and Varya stand before her.
(heavy accent) Did you try cold water?
I tried everything. She won't wake up. Ralph slaps Alice's face.
Hey, you. Wake up. Alice doesn't budge.
(continuing) This is very strange. Varya looks at her watch.
I have another customer in five minutes! I just can't have her sitting here like this. Varya takes Alice by the shoulder.
(continuing) Don't just stand there! Help me move her.
Ralph carries Alice. arya opens the door to a large close and Ralph sets her inside.
What are you going to do with her?  97.
I don't have time to think about that now.
I could use her as a model. She sits very still. Varya closes the closet door, leaving Alice in complete darkness.
Anne wakes to find Elvis sleeping beside her, holding her hand. She slides out of bed carefully, so as not to wake and pads across the floor to the bathroom.

Anne enters her bathroom and closes the door quietly behi her. She leans into the mirror and looks with dismay at t bags under her eyes. She holds up her hand. It is shaking. She pulls open a drawer beside the sink and reaches for a bottle of prescription pain killers. She pops the top and fishes for the pills. She winces, reacting to a terrible flash of pain. Her vision darkens the room starts to swim before her eyes. Another flash of pain, one hundred times stronger than anything she's ever felt before. Her knees fold beneath h like broken matchsticks. She collapses on the cold tile. The aspirin bottle falls, scattering pills around her.

Elvis sits on a bank of chairs. He's been awake for thirt six hours and looks it. Red sits beside him. Part of Anne can be glimpsed through a rectangular window in the adjac room. A NURSE is tending to her. The Colonel approaches Elvis.
How is she?  98. Elvis looks at him, doesn't answer.
Sleeping. The Nurse comes out of Anne's room.
(to Elvis) You can go in if you want.
Anne wakes in the stark hospital room. She is gaunt, colorless, and fragile. Elvis sits beside her, holding hi head in his hands.
Hey -- Elvis looks up and takes her hand.
How are you?
Not so good. You? Elvis shakes his head.
I don't think I can get through this.
You are loved by more people than anyone on earth. Anne closes her eyes. They reopen a moment later.
(continuing) Don't let them put me in a box, I want to be cremated.
All right.
I never saw Graceland.  99.
It's not going anywhere. The slightest hint of a smile from Anne. She closes her eyes. Elvis begins to shake. Losing a battle to fight bac tears he leans over and kisses her
It is the dead of night. POUNDING is heard coming from inside the closet where Alice was deposited.

Let me out! I'm not dead! Somebody help me! More frantic POUNDING. A just-awoken Varya stumbles out of her room in her pajam She clomps down the hall and opens the closet door releas a severely disoriented Alice.
Leave my house and don't ever come back. Alice is ruined.
She told me she was a fake.
Dr. Shemp lives in a swanky high-rise in Santa Monica. He looks a little sleepy and is wearing pajamas, slippers, a robe. Alice sits on his sofa, fighting back tears.
She said I was nuts and that she wouldn't see me anymore. Dr. Shemp passes her a box of tissues. Alice takes one an dries her eyes.
How could I have made all that up?  100.

Your subconscious was trying to heal the wound created by the loss of your fiancee. Since you were not ready to face it in reality, it was cushioning the blow. With most people this process would have manifested itself in simple denial, but since you are a creative person, your subconscious devised a creative solution. Alice is now crying full force. Dr. Shemp's heart goes ou He gets up from his chair and sits beside her. He puts hi arm around her and cradles her head against his shoulder. Alice stiffens. He guides her face towards him and leans in to kiss her. Alice recoils in horror.
What are you doing?
I was going to kiss you. Alice goes pale.
Oh my God. She jumps to her feet, picks up her purse.
You must've known I was attracted to you.
This isn't happening. She grabs her coat and reaches for the door. Dr. Shemp go after her.
Wait, we should talk. Alice can't even look at him.  101.
(continuing) We need to process what's happened here. Ignoring him, Alice pushes through the door and SLAMS it behind her.
Alice gets out of a cab and enters her building. She stil looks completely at sea.
Alice approaches Kevin's door. She finds it slightly ajar She knocks.
Kevin? Alice pushes open the door and enters the apartment. She gasps. Standing in the middle of the room, amongst backpacks and duffel bags is Brian.
Hello, Alice. It's good to see you again.
Brian. Where's Kevin?
I called from the airport. Told him I was coming. He was gone when I got here.
You don't know where he went?
I'm sorry, I don't.
You didn't know him from before?
No. He just answered an ad. Are you guys friends or something?  102. Alice sits, hides her face in her hands.
Are you back for good? Brian sits beside her.
No. I came to pack up the rest of my stuff. We need to talk. Something happened to me in Alaska.

location: OCEAN OFF THE COAST OF ALASKA

text: A salmon fishing boat is anchored off a majestic coastlin

A group of manly, hardened DECK HANDS are hauling in a he net. Brian stands alongside them. He looks a little out o his element, but he's working hard to keep up. He looks to the Deck Hand next to him. He is muscular and deeply tanned. His hair is closely cropped. A prominent tattoo of an anchor has been needled into his bicep. Brian can't remove his eyes from him. The Deck Hand retur his look unflinchingly. An ocean of shared and unspoken knowledge opens up between them.
